Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Cloaking in stratified fluids

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Alam, M.-Reza/Ardekani, Arezoo
Proposal Number: 1414579/1414581
Institution: University of California-Berkeley
Title: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Cloaking in stratified fluids


The objective of the proposed research is to explore the possibility of developing and deploying the equivalent of an "invisibility cloak" to render floating wind energy harvesting turbines invisible to ocean surface waves. Invisibility cloaks, made of metamaterial, have identified as one of the top ten important discoveries in solid state physics, optics, and acoustics in the first decade of 21st century, but this is now being discussed in the context of fluid mechanics and water waves.

Intellectual Merit
An invisibility cloak for an object at the water surface can be accomplished when the surface waves detour the object as if the object does not exist, i.e., when there is no diffraction. An important consequence of such a cloaking is that floating structures and objects in a cloaked region will be protected from powerful incoming surface waves. The proposed research will take first strides into this area in a fluid mechanics context by using a combined theoretical, computational, and experimental approach. The research is focused on the effect of buoyancy jump (typical of oceans and lakes), viscosity, inertia, diffusion, and non-uniformities of seabed topography on cloaking in both sharp and continuous stratified fluids.

Broader Impacts
This research program can lead to designing new strategies to protect moving and stationary ocean objects (ships, submarines, offshore platforms such as wind turbines) from disruptive effects of oceanic waves. In this work, fundamental fluid mechanics will be used to augment this area of aquatic science and oceanography. The proposed research is potentially transformative in that this area of fluid mechanics has to date gone mostly unexplored. The grant will also provide partial support for training two graduate students. The participation of women and members of underrepresented groups will be facilitated through the Women's Engineering Program at University of California Berkeley and Notre Dame. The PIs will ensure the participation of undergraduates through the Undergraduate Research Opportunity Program at both Berkeley and Notre Dame.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many aquatic and marine environments are characterized by vertical variations in water density, termed as pycnoclines. Internal waves form in these stably stratified environments in addition to surface waves formed on the surface of the water body. In this research program, we tested the novel hypothesis whether the nonlinear resonances formed between surface waves, internal gravity waves, and seabed undulations can lead to cloaking of floating objects in aquatic and marine environments. Invisibility cloaks, made of metamaterial, have identified as one of the top ten important discoveries in solid state physics, optics, and acoustics in the first decade of 21st century, but this is the first time it is discussed in the context of fluid mechanics and water waves.

 

The science of invisibility is now entering uncharted waters. We have theoretically shown that by altering the sea floor in the right way, it should be possible to hide an object floating on the sea from passing waves. The technique helps protect ships and floating structures from rough seas. Because the scheme works entirely differently from the “cloaks” developed to hide objects from light and other electromagnetic waves, it breaks new ground for research. We have theoretically proven that unlike the electromagnetic cloaking, a complete cloaking of a broadband of frequencies of incident wave can be achieved. Under the tenure of this grant we were able to find a nonlinear transformation that only requires the change in one of the medium properties which in the case of shallow water waves, can be the water depth while keeping the gravity acceleration intact. This nonlinear transformation therefore enables us to design a perfect cloak for long gravity waves. We have shown that with this nonlinear transformation an object can be cloaked to any wave that merely has to satisfy the long wave assumption.

 

We have also designed a Wave Bridge which has a potential to reduce the maintenance costs of offshore structures (such as wind turbines and oil rigs) by reducing the wave loads and providing calm water in the midst of an energetic and turbulent ocean. A wave bridge is designed to bypass the momentum of oceanic waves around the structure. It is based on the concept of broadband oceanic wave protection mechanism which can theoretically be used both in shallow and deep waters, making it a potentially transformative concept. The novelty of the idea has been featured as the cover page of a leading scientific magazine, American Scientist. The theoretical results have been supported by experimental results which show that it is possible to achieve wave protection efficiencies of up to 97% and horizontal force protection efficiencies of up to 80%, in cases where the frequency of the incident waves was equal to the natural frequency of the wave bridge.

 

One of the objectives of this proposal is to investigate whether cloaking happens in continuously stratified fluids. We have approached this problem analytically and numerically. We proved that in the presence of bottom topography, Bragg resonance may occur in a continuously stratified fluid when their wavenumbers and frequency satisfy resonance conditions. We derived the governing equation for wave propagation from full nonlinear Euler equation considering density stratification and Boussinesq approximation.

 

We have also developed numerical tools to further quantify cloaking and internal wave formation in density stratified fluids. We have performed successful simulations of resonance condition that exists between surface waves and undulated bottom topographies.
